intro: Quercus frainetto, commonly known as the Hungarian oak, is a deciduous tree native to Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn golden in the fall. The tree produces small, spiky capsules that contain one or two seeds. It typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and has a broad, spreading canopy. The bark is grey and becomes fissured with age, providing a distinctive appearance.
